Award.AwardTitle: RAPID/Collaborative Research: Digitizing Early Cretaceous dinosaur trackways to preserve the geological heritage of central Texas
Award.AbstractNarration: Dinosaur tracks and trackways provide invaluable information about ancient lifeforms and are of great interest to the general public. Yet, increasing urbanization jeopardizes their preservation. This is especially true in central Texas where the metropolitan population grows by 1.7% yearly, and puts dinosaur tracksites exposed in rural areas and creeks at risk. Other sources of destruction include transient flood and weathering enhanced by climate change. This proposal will preserve three important sites in a digital format using advanced imagery techniques and will include analysis of collected rock samples to provide information about the landscape where these dinosaurs lived. New data will be integrated into the Witte Museum in San Antonio, Texas, where it can be used for scientific research and to educate the general public on preservation best practice and the ecology of life in central Texas about 110 million years ago. This project will engage researchers from four institutions with a strong track record on the topic and they will mentor non-traditional graduate and undergraduate students to solidify their interest in the geosciences and retain them in the major. <br/><br/>This project will inform on the depositional environment and the conditions that promoted the preservation of trace fossils. The digitization of each site using photogrammetric techniques will be complemented by detailed analysis of rock samples using microscopy and geochemistry. Results will evaluate whether dinosaur tracks are preferentially preserved in shallow marine sediments deposited during periods of sea-level fall, when their frequent subaerial exposure under a hot and dry climate favored their early lithification and preservation. Alternatively, preservation may be enhanced by rapid burial with clay-rich sediment in a hot and humid environment. Geochemical and petrographic data also will be used to test these hypotheses. The integration of all results in a database available to researchers and the general public will showcase the cultural heritage of Texas and serve as a basis for future research.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Dinosaur tracks are common in the Lower Cretaceous Glen Rose Formation of central Texas.  The Glen Rose Formation was deposited in marine environments representing the ancient shoreline of the Gulf of Mexico. The track sites record the environments that existed as dinosaurs walked along the shoreline.  Many sites are important historically for the early documentation of dinosaur tracks and for early interpretations of dinosaur behavior such as herding and swimming. The track sites have received little previous study of the details of the ancient environments. Furthermore, many of the sites are vulnerable to destruction from the processes of weathering, stream erosion, and urbanization.  The goals of this project are to 1) preserve the track-site records through digital archives of photogrammetry data of the tracks, and the sedimentologic and geochemical data on the environments, and to 2) use sedimentologic and geochemical data to provide detailed interpretations of environments in which the dinosaurs lived and the conditions that led to the preservation of the tracks.

Our research focused on three sites: the Startzville site, the Mayan Ranch in Bandera, and the Davenport Ranch in Bandera.  In all three sites the sedimentary rocks record fluctuations in sea level with shifts from very shallow shoreline tidal-flat environments to offshore open marine environments. In all of the sites the track surface is in a limestone containing sedimentary structures indicating very shallow marine to tidal flat environments. Carbon and oxygen isotope ratios in the track surface point to chemical alteration of the sediment during exposure to the atmosphere and rainfall. In all three sites the track surfaces are overlain by mudrock or clay-rich limestone containing chemical evidence for greater input of silicate material (aluminum, silica, and titanium) and micronutrients (barium, nickel, copper, iron, phosphorus) that are interpreted to have been transported from land into the shoreline by river or wind. These observations indicate that burial by silicate sediment input from land played an important role in preservation of the tracks.   The chemical index of alteration (CIA), calculated as the ratio of aluminum to the sum of calcium, sodium and potassium, is interpreted to reflect intensity of weathering in the landward silicate sediment source area.  The CIA values for geochemical data collected at the sites is consistent with a high intensity of chemical weathering indicating a generally hot and humid climate.

The track surfaces at the Startzville and the Mayan Ranch localities are undertracks where the impressions preserved today are the result of registration of the track deformation into sediments underlying the actual track surface. The actual track surface was stripped away by erosion.  The manus (or front foot) dominated sauropod trackway at the Mayan Ranch locality was interpreted by R.T. Bird (1954) to be formed by a swimming sauropod.  Sedimentologic evidence from this site rules out the swimming sauropod hypothesis and indicates that the manus dominant tracks are an artifact of undertrack preservation.  Also, at the Mayan Ranch site, early marine lithification of the carbonate sediments reduced the depth of registration of the tracks by stiffening the surface that the dinosaurs walked on. The presence of pressure rims, claw and pad impressions indicate the preservation of the original track surfaces at the Davenport Ranch. The Davenport Ranch site shows evidence of an arid paleoclimate with gypsum precipitated in the carbonate sediments of one of the track surfaces. The low diversity of marine invertebrate fossils and greater alteration of the carbonate sediment by magnesium waters at this locality also point to aridity. Upward decrease in CIA at this site indicates progressively greater aridity and reduced intensity of chemical weathering through time at this site.

This project has produced a digital data archive that will be housed at the Witte Museum.  Results from this project have been used in the development of educational materials for teaching high school and introductory college field projects on making observations, gathering data on trackways, and using the data to test hypotheses and to draw conclusions on the size, speed and behavior of the dinosaurs and the paleoenvironments represented in the rock record.  This project supported three undergraduate student projects at Trinity University, an undergraduate student project and a Ph.D. project at The University of Texas San Antonio. Students were mentored by a multidisciplinary team of professors from Trinity University, The University of Texas San Antonio, The University of Kansas, Kansas State University, and the Witte Museum.
